Baja Indonesia Kena Bea Masuk di Cina, Luhut Protes ke Jinping
06 Nov 2019, 04:48 by Bisnis.com, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Menteri Koordinator Kemaritiman dan Investasi Luhut Binsar Panjaitan menyatakan keberatannya atas penerapan bea masuk impor baja asal Indonesia di Cina. Saat bertemu dengan Presiden China Xi Jinping, Luhut langsung meminta Beijing untuk meringankan atau bahkan menghapus bea masuk impor produk baja asal Indonesia.
Dalam pertemuan singkat di sela China International Import Expo (CIIE) yang berlangsung pada 5-10 November tersebut, Luhut dan Presiden Jinping membicarakan kondisi terakhir eskpor Indonesia. Indonesia berharap bisa meningkatkan ekspornya ke Cina karena negara itu memiliki pasar yang massif dengan penduduk yang mencapai 1,4 miliar orang.
“Terutama ekspor buah-buahan tropis seperti nanas, lalu sarang burung, ekspor kelapa sawit juga masih bisa kita tingkatkan. Lalu ada olahan-olahan produk hilirisasi seperti nickel ore, tembaga, timah, bauksit dan banyak lagi. Presiden Xi tadi berjanji untuk meningkatkan investasi negaranya di bidang teknologi,” kata Luhut seperti dilansir Bisnis, Rabu 6 November 2019.
Selain dengan Cina, pada kesempatan itu Luhut juga bertemu dengan perwakilan pebisnis dari AS dalam rangka membicarakan isu yang sama. Pengusaha asal AS yang menjadi pemasok baja ke AS dari Indonesia menyampaikan permasalahan mereka yakni adanya bea masuk sebesar 25 persen atas produk baja yang mereka suplai.
“Besok dalam pertemuan dengan Menteri Perdagangan Wilbur Ross, saya akan sampaikan hal ini dan minta kebijakan AS untuk memberi keringanan,” janji Menko Luhut.
Luhut menerangkan, bahwa kebijakan pengenaan bea masuk tersebut cukup memberatkan karena produk baja yang dikenai bea masuk diproduksi di daerah terpencil dan masyarakat pun terkena dampak dari pengenaan bea tersebut.
“Hanya Jepang, Korea Selatan dan Turki mendapat pengecualian tarif masuk ini. Kita kan negara berkembang tentu ini menyulitkan bagi Indonesia,” kata Luhut.

Indonesian Steel Subjects to Import Duty in China, Luhut Protests to Jinping
Nov 6 2019, 04:48 by Bisnis.com, Rahma Tri
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Coordinating Minister for Maritime Affairs and Investment Luhut Binsar Panjaitan expressed his objection to the application of import duties on Indonesian steel imports in China. When meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping, Luhut immediately asked Beijing to ease or even remove import duties on Indonesian steel products.
In a brief meeting on the sidelines of the China International Import Expo (CIIE) which took place on 5-10 November, Luhut and President Jinping discussed the latest conditions of Indonesian exports. Indonesia hopes to increase its exports to China because it has a massive market with a population of 1.4 billion people.
"Especially the export of tropical fruits such as pineapple, then bird nests, palm oil exports can also be improved. Then there are processed downstream products such as nickel ore, copper, tin, bauxite and more. President Xi had promised to increase his country's investment in technology, "Luhut said as reported by Bisnis, Wednesday, November 6, 2019.
In addition to China, on that occasion Luhut also met with representatives of business people from the US in order to discuss the same issue. US entrepreneurs who are suppliers of steel to the US from Indonesia conveyed their problem, namely the 25 percent import duty on the steel products they supply.
"Tomorrow in a meeting with the Minister of Trade Wilbur Ross, I will convey this and ask for US policy to provide relief," promised Coordinating Minister Luhut.
Luhut explained, that the policy of imposing the import duty was quite burdensome because steel products that were subject to import duties were produced in remote areas and the community was affected by the imposition of such duties.
"Only Japan, South Korea and Turkey have this exemption. We are a developing country, this is certainly difficult for Indonesia, "said Luhut.
